title-group.article-title: Inferring the Components of the Bid-Ask Spread: Theory and Empirical Tests

abstract.p: The relation between the square of the quoted bid-ask spread and two serial covariances--the serial covariance of transaction returns and the serial covariance of quoted returns--is modeled as a function of the probability of a price reversal, π, and the magnitude of a price change, ∂, where ∂ is stated as a fraction of the quoted spread. Different models of the spread are contrasted in terms of the parameters, π and ∂. Using data on the transaction prices and price quotations for NASDAQ/NMS stocks, π and ∂ are estimated and the relative importance of the components of the quoted spread--adverse information costs, order processing costs, and inventory holding costs--is determined.
